docs.lead_paragraph: Democratic candidates are trying to figure out whether to embrace or avoid President Barack Obama's health care overhaul — or land somewhere in between.

headline.main: Health Law: Embrace, Avoid or in Between for Dems
headline.print_headline: Health Law: Embrace, Avoid or in Between for Dems

docs.snippet: Democratic candidates are trying to figure out whether to embrace or avoid President Barack Obama's health care overhaul — or land somewhere in between.

docs.lead_paragraph: Belgian insurance company Ageas said on Monday it had paid 122.5 million euros ($167 million) to acquire the non-life activities of its Portuguese joint venture with Millenniumbcp.

headline.main: Ageas Buys Non-Life Insurance From Portuguese Venture
headline.print_headline: Ageas Buys Non-Life Insurance From Portuguese Venture

docs.snippet: Belgian insurance company Ageas said on Monday it had paid 122.5 million euros ($167 million) to acquire the non-life activities of its Portuguese joint venture with Millenniumbcp.

docs.lead_paragraph: With less than two weeks before ballots are counted, details about health care and retroactive pay are the biggest concerns among New York City teachers.

headline.main: As Ballot Count Nears, City’s Teachers Debate Whether to Ratify Contract
headline.print_headline: As Ballot Count Nears, City’s Teachers Debate Whether to Ratify Contract

docs.abstract: Many New York City teachers are still debating whether to ratify agreement that United Federation of Teachers reached with the de Blasio administration; as vote approaches, details about heath care and retroactive pay are among their biggest concerns.
docs.snippet: With less than two weeks before ballots are counted, details about health care and retroactive pay are the biggest concerns among New York City teachers.

docs.lead_paragraph: Several carriers that have been sitting on the sidelines say they will join the exchanges or expand their offerings to more states.

headline.main: Insurers Once on the Fence Plan to Join Health Exchanges in ’15
headline.print_headline: Insurers Once on the Fence Plan to Join Health Exchanges in ’15

docs.abstract: Several health care insurers that have been sitting on the sidelines say they will sell policies on the new federal health insurance exchanges in coming year, and others plan to expand their offerings to more states; shift is sign of growing business potential under federal health care law.
docs.snippet: Several carriers that have been sitting on the sidelines say they will join the exchanges or expand their offerings to more states.

docs.lead_paragraph: Some systems have started scaling back financial assistance for lower- and middle-income people without health insurance, hoping to push them to sign up for coverage through online marketplaces.

headline.main: Hospitals Look to Health Law, Cutting Charity
headline.print_headline: Hospitals Look to Health Law, Cutting Charity

docs.abstract: Some hospital systems around country are cutting back on financial assistance for low- and middle-income people who lack health insurance, and are attempting to push many such people into signing up for insurance under Affordable Care Act; movement is worrisome to advocates for uninsured, who say that many will opt to forgo care rather than purchase insurance they consider unaffordable; high cost of charity care is factor in trend.
docs.snippet: Some systems have started scaling back financial assistance for lower- and middle-income people without health insurance, hoping to push them to sign up for coverage through online marketplaces.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: Employers have been told they cannot give their workers a tax-free lump sum to cover their health insurance costs, a change that could disrupt arrangements in many industries.

headline.main: I.R.S. Bars Employers From Dumping Workers Into Health Exchanges
headline.print_headline: I.R.S. Bars Employers From Dumping Workers Into Health Exchanges

docs.abstract: Internal Revenue Service rules that employers may not cease providing health insurance in favor of giving employees tax-free contributions to help pay premiums for policies bought on health insurance exchange.
docs.snippet: Employers have been told they cannot give their workers a tax-free lump sum to cover their health insurance costs, a change that could disrupt arrangements in many industries.

docs.lead_paragraph: Two businesses that have traditionally been separate, even adversarial, are starting to team up. It’s worth asking what the implications are.

docs.lead_paragraph: Sovaldi is considered a breakthrough for treating hepatitis C. But at about $1,000 a pill, it is raising questions about how available it will be to those who receive government-subsidized health care.

headline.main: Cost of New Drug Complicates Access for Inmates and the Poor
headline.print_headline: Cost of New Drug Complicates Access for Inmates and the Poor

docs.snippet: Sovaldi is considered a breakthrough for treating hepatitis C. But at about $1,000 a pill, it is raising questions about how available it will be to those who receive government-subsidized health care.
